That Sherlock quote annoys me … no matter how people try to rescue it, it's false.

After eliminating the impossible, whatever remains must be POSSIBLE. <-- we can agree with this.  To say that we are left with the truth indicates that there is no such thing as possibility... only truths and impossibilities.  This is patently absurd.  If I shake a die in an opaque jar... it lands on a number.  If I shake it again, before anyone has a chance to look inside... then there is no reasonable method to determine the number it landed on.

Sir Arthur Conan Doyle would have you believe that by eliminating that the die disappeared, that it turned into a sheep, or that it landed on a corner... one can deduce the truth.  One cannot.  One can only deduce that it most likely landed on one of the numbered sides.

Tell me what impossible things you would eliminate to correctly determine which side.  Impossible things are easy to eliminate - they're impossible after all... or, admit that eliminating the impossible is not at all useful in determining truth unless, in doing so, one can also eliminate all but one of the possibilities.

Calling it the perfect example of abduction doesn't make it a valid statement.  It just makes me question abduction.


Similarly, with the Anna abduction which follows.  It is only valid to conclude that there is a possibility that Anna dropped physics.  The conclusion "Anna dropped physics" is unsound... it may also be that she's completed her work for the year, has asked to change class or does not need to attend for some reason.  She may also just be slacking off lectures in a subject she knows well, to focus on catching up with some subject she's struggling with.

"Anna dropped physics" is at best a guess, not a conclusion.  "Anna may have dropped physics" is a conclusion.

Boldly making sloppy statements, from sloppy reasoning, is the antithesis of logic.  Giving it a cool name, doesn't legitimise it. Basically, if you use abduction, your conclusion MUST contain an expression of uncertainty, otherwise it's WRONG.

There IS no Grue before time 't' … since it's impossible for any substance to have the proper characteristics of Grue yet. Surely the proper inference is that, if Grue exists, then SOME items (emeralds for example) could be Grue… but equally, may not be.

Sure, the emerald meets SOME of the definitions of Grue … but that's like saying a wheelbarrow IS a car, because it has at least one wheel, and all cars have at least one wheel. And logistician would consider this a fundamental error in reasoning, and not worth pursuing any further.

Furthermore since no person has ever experienced Grue… ever! ...it would be unreasonable and an inductive error to consider that emeralds are Grue even if Grue exists. There simply isn't any grounds for any such expectations. Only if Grue were cyclic could we make an inference based on prior experience (whether that be personal or anecdotal) … till then, we're taking it on faith that any green thing will change colour to blue in response to the time.

So, I fail to see the point about Grue : / Perhaps Nelson Goodmans argument was considerably more nuanced than is presented here.

Notes on Crashcourse Philosophy Video 3: How to Argue-Induction and Abduction







Induction: uses past experience to make future predictions. Relies on predictability of nature, the fact that the future will resemble the past.


In deductive reasoning, true premises mean you have a true conclusion


In inductive reasoning, true premises mean you have a LIKELY conclusion 
Ex: most men in Athens had beards. Socrates was a man in Athens. Therefore Socrates likely had a beard.


Nelson Goodman (contemporary American philosopher) flash philosophy:
A substance called grue is a substance that is green before a certain time. It’s blue after that certain time. We live before that time, and all the emeralds we’ve ever seen are green. We inductively reason that all emeralds are green and that they will remain green. But we also think that these emeralds are grue because they are green, so they will probably turn blue after the specified time. Takeaway: inductive evidence can be flawed or contradictory.


Sherlock Holmes
Said to eliminate the impossible to get at the truth


Abduction: draw a conclusion based on explanation that best explains state of affairs, rather than evidence from the premises (inference to the best explanation)


Example of Abductive argument:  Anna said she failed her physics midterm. She hasn’t been in class since the exams were graded. She has been in sociology which meets right after physics. Therefore, she dropped physics.


We can’t inductively or deductively draw a conclusion here, so we use abduction to explain what happened. Note: abduction doesn’t give certain conclusions like deduction.


Doctors and detectives use abduction to account for the facts they are given and explain these facts.


Interlocutors are people that participate in a debate or conversation. When in a debate, you need to give reasons to back up your conclusions. 


The Socratic Method: learn through a dialectic exchange of ideas (exchange ideas in a conversation)


Aim of dialogue: bring interlocutors closer to truth




Questions: 




Define induction. How is it different from deductive reasoning? Define abduction and give an example. Which philosopher famously used induction to solve cases? Can abduction offer certain conclusions? What is the Socratic Method?

As an interim point, I do not believe aspirin will cure my headache.  This is a non-sequitur.  The active ingredient in aspirin, acetylsalicylic acid, is used as an NSAID (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug), and as a blood thinner.  The simple fact is, if some drug company (or anyone, for that matter) tried to get aspirin through the FDA's drug trials as a pain reliever today, it would fail - miserably.  It was 'grandfathered' in, because it had been used for so long, and because people trusted it, and because there was already so much of it out there, and it didn't cause any actual harm, they just decided to accept it without rigorous trials.  If you want to relieve pain, use acetaminophen or ibuprofen.  Those actually do relieve pain.                                          Rikki Tikki.

Your Socrates induction example is not actually induction. Here is the same example worded slightly differently:
1. If 90% of men in ancient Athens have a beard...
2. ...and I select one of these men at random...
3. ...there is a 90% probability that he will have a beard.
In other words, your example is actually deduction.

Here is what induction actually is:
1. Every man in ancient Athens that I have ever met...
2 ...turned out to have a beard.
3. Therefore, it's likely that every man in ancient Athens has a beard.
(Also, I would not say that inductive arguments "work in terms of probabilities" because this reasoning, in isolation, can't give you the probability* that your conclusion in 3 is correct, the so-called "prosecutor's fallacy.

*Unless you know that you've met every man in ancient Athens, but then that becomes deduction again:
1. If every man I've met in ancient Athens has a beard...
2. ...and I've met them every man in ancient Athens...
3. ...then every man in ancient Athens has a beard.)

I think there is a mistake. Your inductive argument is actually a fallacius deductive argument. It follows the structure of deductive arguments:
Most men in ancient Athens had beard-> RULE
Socrates was a man who lived in ancient Athens->CASE
Socrates probably had beard->RESULT

Same as your deductive example:

All human are mortal-> RULE
Socrates is a human->CASE
Socrates is mortal->RESULT

An inductive argument would have a different structure:

1º Socrates was a man who used to live in Ancient Athens -> CASE
2º Socrates had a beard -> RESULT
3º Men in ancient Athens used to had a beard -> RULE


Again we can not trust the truth of this argument, it is actually a hurried generalization, it is what happens when your induction has not a wide experience as a base. BUT THAT IS THE STRUCTURE OF INDUCTION: CASE, RESULT, RULE.

Gorgias's gossip is itself evidence that Socrates had a beard.

If Socrates didn't have one, it wouldn't make any sense to accuse him of faking it. A beard must have been there for Gorgias to have something to impugn. Not only did most men have beards, but we have testimony that he did. We might mistrust his motives and find the fake-beard part of his story implausible, but it is more probably that he was speaking slander, rather than a complete non sequitur of accusing a man with no beard at all of having a fake beard.

A Socrates fanatic might exaggerate or fabricate a beard to favor his reputation. But Gorgias is unwillingly giving away evidence in Socrates's favor. It's like the riddle of the two guards, one who always lies and one who always tells the truth. You can get the truth out of the liar if you frame the question the right way.

It's also worth noting that abduction depends on induction (or is a form of induction, if by induction you simply mean 'less than demonstrative inference). How can one explanation be preferred to another explanation? By noting how inductive considerations, ultimately based on statistical correlation, support one explanation over the others available.

Also, Holmes' explanation of deduction is famously nonsensical ... 'when you've eliminated the impossible, whatever is left, no matter how improbable, must be the truth'. It truly is guesswork ... just very well done guesswork.

Deductions, inductions and abductions are all permutations of the order of premises and conclusions.

Deduction: (Premise 1) all ravens are black; (Premise 2) Merle is a raven; (Conclusion) Merle is black.
Induction: (Premise 1) Merle is a raven; (Premise 2) Merle is black; (Conclusion) all ravens are black.
Abduction: (Premise 1) Merle is black; (Premise 2) all ravens are black; (Conclusion) Merle is a raven.

Reversing the order of the premises doesn't change the validity of each argument and hence all six permutations are accounted for. Hence, deduction, induction and abduction exhaust all possible two premised arguments. Two premised arguments are simplifications of any iterative list of premises and by extension deduction, induction and abduction exhaust all possible forms of argumentation.

What @crashcourse calls "induction" at 2:42 is what I'd call "abduction" to differentiate it from iterative generalization from particular black ravens to the universal generalization that all ravens are black. Abductions, just like deductions, reason from universals to particulars yet are deductively invalid. Inductions reason from particulars to universals, which was why Hume was skeptical that they could ever be certain. No matter how many ravens were observed to be black, there could always be a unobserved raven out there that wasn't black.

Socrates' beardedness has nothing to do with whether the future resembles the past because the conclusion of the argument at 2:42 isn't a generalized statement. Even if Socrates were to shave his beard, the statement 'Socrates probably had a beard' would still be true just in case the generalization 'Most men in ancient Athens had beards' were true. What would make the probability false would be if in the future (from the perspective of ancient Athens) most Athenian men started shaving. To make the argument inductive, we must permute the order of statements to the following: (1) Socrates was a man that lived in ancient Athens; (2) Socrates probably had a beard; (C) most men in ancient Athens had beards. Notice that this argument isn't even inductively valid, since we still must change the concluding statement to 'most men in ancient Athens probably had beards' as the probability of the conclusion of an inductive argument can be no greater than the probability of each of the premises.

Wow, wow. The example of Socrates was NOT and inductive argument. That was still deduction: the conclusion followed from the premises. What is an inductive argument is the conclusion that on earth gravity always pulls down, based on the fact that you've never seen it pull up; or that the sun will come up tomorrow because it always has in the past; or that all swans are not-pink, because you've never seen a pink swan.

Basically: I've seen X a hundred times, so it must always be true.

You do not know with certainty that there is no pink swan, because to know this, you need to examine EVERY swan that has ever lived. That is to say, induction are shortcut conclusions based on previous facts that cannot be proven to be certain (You might very well encounter a pink swan today).

A good introduction but a few things could be fixed up a bit. Firstly, Goodman's new riddle of induction isn't meant to simply illustrate that inductive reasoning can lead us astray. No one would ever accept an argument like the one provided concerning 'grue', so there is no need to worry. What it instead shows us is that there are some predicates that are more suitable for use in inductive reasoning than others (he calls these predicates 'projectible'). The real riddle comes from trying to explain what it is about green that makes it a projectible predicate; it has to be something that isn't also true about grue and it can't merely take for granted that green is projectible while grue isn't.
Secondly, the Socratic Method isn't just 'exchanging ideas through dialogue' or the type of back-in-forth argument presented in the video. The Socratic Method refers to an argumentative technique used by Socrates (mostly) in Plato's early or 'Socratic' dialogues (referred to as such for just this reason). Socrates specifically asks his interlocutors to define some nebulous concept like 'justice', 'piety', 'knowledge', etc. and then criticizes their proposed definitions. Ultimately, Socrates shows that they have failed to give any satisfactory definition. That being said, I have a feeling that Hank is planning on starting with Socrates next week, so I can see why he would try to make this connection.

You can't prove that peanut m&m's are better than chocolate m&m's by taste related satisfaction. Because immediate taste preference between individuals is completely subjective. You COULD give arguments as to which are objectively better on another standard. You COULD say that one is technically healthier than another, which would be  good as it would possibly lead to greater satisfaction down the line in that you will feel healthier and/or die later than you would have otherwise, therefore you ought to like those M&Ms. You could say that the process to make one is more sustainable than the other. Maybe peanut farming is more intensive than farming the various other ingredients in M&Ms, therefore you ought to like regular M&Ms more. And you could associate behavioral arguments with this. Maybe if you form a habit of eating M&M's you are just as likely to eat as many of either M&M's per unit time, no matter their properties, therefore plain M&M's are better because they contain fewer calories and cost fewer resources to make. Or Peanut M&M's are better because, despite increased caloric intake, the calories are made more nutritious by the peanuts, and that nutrition is most important. But as far as food goes, the best thing that you could do for sustainability and nutrition or the ethics of creating the product in the first place for any food choice would be to drink Soylent, which is basically this liquid mixture of perfectly balanced nutritional and caloric needs met with very sustainable production and it produced without any animal products. So what you OUGHT to like the most is Soylent, and you OUGHT to like it so much that you could never dream of consuming another thing again. Except human beings taste buds and neural interpretations of taste based stimuli aren't actively chosen by you. You are forced to taste what you taste. You can't force your taste buds to prefer plain M&M's to Peanut M&Ms any more than you can force your taste buds to make broccoli taste like cake. Each person is satisfied by their own things. And as long as the consequence of doing a thing is not so egregious that it will necessarily be of great harm to everyone else, it ought to be allowed and encouraged.

Part of the socratic method is to ask questions. When you want to teach something to someone, the best way of making someone truly understand you is making them get to the conclusion themselves, so you ask questions that will guide them into a correct answer. They're not trick questions, or questions that without context can't be answered properly (you know, like the questions that a lawyer does to try to incriminate someone), but open questions that have logical answers.

And this (induction) is why we have so many preconceptions about people from other groups (racial, national, political, religious, etc.), especially if there has been no contact with them.  Sometimes, having had contact with them, some of the preconceptions will be confirmed or disproven, but only for that person; yet, we love generalizing from past experiences.

If you take a course in logic this is not how induction works.

Induction works as follows:
You have an hypothesis.

You have a finite number of basecases (e.g. n=0, n=1, n=2)
And you have an inductive step (If n holds then n+1 must hold too)

It is based on the idea that if you prove that it holds for case n=0 and you prove that case n implies case n+1 then for all n>0 must our hypothesis must hold.
The inductive step is often accompanied with an invariant which requires additional information to be trough at n and n+1 but additional information often gives the option of additional conclusions.


This form of induction is one of the most useful concepts logic has to offer. It gives us the possibility to prove things for infinite sets without considering every case. And can be used to prove equivalence between recursive and non-recursive functions.

One of my favorite stories about philosophy is the following; a Greek farmer has a son whom he aspires to raise above his class and he sends the boy to law school under a philosopher, whom has given the farmer a good deal.

"I'll teach your boy to be a great lawyer; you can pay me when he has won his first case."

And so it goes; the philosopher teaches the lawyer proper reasoning skills and everything that he needs to win cases. However, after 1 year of studying and the conclusion of the philosopher's guidance, the son decides that he likes the money he was given by his father more and keeps it.

The philosopher is outraged and he drags the son to court. There, they debate and argue for days, until the philosopher concludes his argument;

"Wise members of the jury, truly this debate is for naught. For you see; should this boy win the case, he will have won his first case, thereby fulfilling the requirements of the deal I have with him. If he loses his case, you will order him to pay. Therefore, he will pay me once this case is done."

The boy then counters, "Wise members of the jury, my master is mistaken and has taught me nothing if this is his argument. For you see, if I lose this case, I still haven't fulfilled the requirements of our deal. But if I win, you will have acquited me from paying. Therefore, I owe him nothing."

Charles Peirce is an amazing philosopher to consult, if you want to memorize the three types of reasoning down really well! He defined the three types of arguments in terms of rules, cases, and results.

Deductive: we begin with a RULE and apply it to a CASE to generate a RESULT

Inductive: we observe a CASE and its RESULT to infer a RULE

Abductive: we observe a RESULT, consider a RULE(s), and create a CASE

Just in case this confusion arises: Mathematical Induction is not the same as Inductive Reasoning. Mathematical Induction is in fact an example of deductive reasoning based on the following inference:

If S(0) and S(i) ==> S(i+1) then S(x) holds for all x.

The interesting thing about the Socrates Beard exchange is that the first counterargument actually strengthens the idea that Socrates had a beard.  The first statement (that Socrates has a beard) has a lot of different possibilities besides the most probable one (for example, Socrates didn't have a beard because he didn't want one). The counterargument (that Socrates had a fake beard) basically admits that Socrates at least appeared to have a beard.  This leaves for two possibilities: 1) Socrates had a fake beard or 2) Socrates had a real beard.  The possibility that Socrates had a real beard is the much more likely of the two, therefore one can now say with even more certainty that Socrates had a beard.

You should have used Hume's thought experiment regarding the sun instead of the grue thought experiment. Hume's favorite example: our belief that the sun will rise tomorrow. Clearly, this is a matter of fact; it rests on our conviction that each sunrise is an effect caused by the rotation of the earth. But our belief in that causal relation is based on past observations, and our confidence that it will continue tomorrow cannot be justified by reference to the past. So we have no rational basis for believing that the sun will rise tomorrow. Yet we do believe it!

It should be noted that not all inductive arguments are based on patterns from experience. Mathematical induction is a very specific type of inductive argument, wherein you prove a conclusion definitively by making an observation, and then using some manner of step-wise proof, proving that this one observation will always hold true for items in a certain class. For example, if you want to prove that 11^n - 6 is divisible by 5 for positive n:

Let n=k=1
11^1 - 6 = 5, divisible by 5.
Therefore our argument has a basis.

Let n=k+1
11^k+1 - 6 = 11 * 11^k -6
= 11 * (5m+6) -6 (using the basis as part of the argument)
= 11(5m) + 60
= 5(11m+12)
This proves that every time you increase n by 1, the result is still divisible by 5.

Therefore, for every positive n, 11^n-6 is divisible by 5.

This is supremely useful in mathematics and computer science, especially in algorithm design.

It would be interesting to examine the relationship of abduction to the disputes about anecdotes vs. data with regard to various scientific, medical, and nutritional controversies. I've had the impression for a long time that there's a certain sort of science lover who reflexively responds to any recounting of personal experience on these topics by saying -- or shouting -- "The plural of anecdote is not data!" or something similar. I think this response misses the point, at least sometimes. One need not be claiming scientifically valid conclusions in order to have perfectly legitimate personal conclusions, achieved abductively, on issues such as the effects of various supplements, medications, and foods, for example. (Of course this is not to deny that one can, and many certainly do, deceive themselves on these matters.)
